III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section Rule 126. The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
Description administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and other
staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency’s program statement and to
provide for the continual needs, protection, and supervision of
residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Since November 2022, a youth at the facility had been dating an
18-year-old youth at the facility and had been engaged in a sexual
relationship. The sexual interactions became non-consensual
overtime. The 18-year-old has left the facility for the time being.
Investigation The complainant was interviewed on 01/24/2023 over the phone.
No additional information was provided outside of what was
previously alleged.
The Administrator and Clinical Director were interviewed in
person during an unannounced face-to-face visit on 01/24/2023.
Documentation was provided and staff information and phone
numbers were gathered. It was confirmed that Youth B was no
longer placed at the facility.
Caseworker 1 was interviewed over the phone on 02/13/2023.
She stated that she had heard allegations from Youth B that there
had been inappropriate contact between her and Youth A but that
those allegations also have been recanted by Youth B later.
Caseworker 1 confirmed that Youth B had been moved out of the
facility as a result of these behaviors as well as other concerning
behaviors. She stated that she did not have any concerns about
the supervision provided by the facility during Youth B’s
placement. She stated that it seemed pretty “locked down.”
Caseworker 1 stated that she had been in constant contact with
the staff at the facility as concerns about Youth B‘s behavior were
witnessed and began to come out. She participated in safety
planning with them immediately after Youth B’s placement in order
to address any concerns.
2

Clinical Director was interviewed on 02/21/2023 during an
announced face-to-face visit at the facility. He confirmed that
Youth A had an unplanned discharged the night prior after some
concerning behaviors and an AWOL attempt.
Therapist was interviewed on 02/21/2023 during an announced
face-to-face visit at the facility. She stated that she had had day-
to-day interaction with both Youth A and Youth B in the unit as
well as in treatment through individual and group therapy.
Therapist stated that she had heard early on that Youth A and
Youth B knew each other from a previous placement, and that she
saw them in groups displaying inappropriate nonverbal behaviors
towards each other early on in their placement. Therapist stated
that staff had caught the two youths passing notes between each
other shortly after. She also recalled that Youth B had to have her
bedroom moved over the course of her short stay in placement
because of concerns between her and Youth A.
Youth C, Youth D, Youth E and Youth F were interviewed during
an announced face-to-face visit to the facility and 02/21/2023. All
four youth stated that they had not witnessed Youth A and Youth
B have any physical interactions but that they had heard that there
might have been attempts to sneak away from staff. None were
able to confirm seeing specific instances of inappropriate
behaviors between the two youths or a lack of staff awareness of
Youth A or Youth B during their time placed at the facility. All four
interviewees stated that they had witnessed interactions between
Youth A and Youth B that amounted to flirtations or inappropriate
comments but none that had advanced beyond that. All youth
described similar interactions and routines with staff and
described sufficient supervisory acts on behalf of staff.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed during an announced face-to-face
visit to the facility on 02/21/2023. She confirmed that she is a
direct care staff supervisor as well as the author of the facility’s
PREA report. Supervisor 1 stated that she believed there were
immediate concerns between Youth A and Youth B upon Youth
B’s placement at the facility in late December. She recalled
discussing the passing of notes and staff addressing inappropriate
comments between the two youth during that time. Supervisor 1
stated that she had multiple conversations with both Youth A and
Youth B during late December about concerning behaviors that
have been witnessed and how to behave in a safer manner.
Supervisor 1 also stated that these behaviors were discussed
during team meetings and provided documentation. Supervisor 1
3

recalled a significant safety plan being developed for Youth B in
early January, as well as Youth B’s room being moved away from
Youth A around that same time. She stated that while she was
confident that two youth having rooms next to or across the
hallway from each other would not directly cause concern as far
as when youth entering another youth’s room when they were not
supposed to, she stated that the decision to move Youth B down
the hallway created less of a chance of passing notes or
nonverbal communication through their room windows. Supervisor
1 did state that youth in the program are not allowed to have
coverings over their windows for the first 30 days of placement.
Supervisor 1 stated that despite the concern with nonverbal
behaviors, inappropriate comments to each other as well as
attempts to pass notes that were caught by staff, she was not
aware of any further behaviors between the two youth as alleged.
Supervisor 1 also confirmed that a new camera had been installed
in late January to cover the bedroom hallway and provide greater
supervision of youth within the units.
Staff 1 was interviewed during an announced face-to-face visit to
the facility on 02/21/2023. She stated that she remembered the
concerns of behavior between Youth A and Youth B in their time
placed at the facility together. Staff 1 would follow the two around
constantly to attempt to keep supervision. She believed that their
behaviors together were noticed almost immediately by her and
other staff. Staff 1 stated that she heard in a team meeting upon
Youth B’s placement at the facility that she had a history of
creating relationships with other youth placed. Staff 1 stated that
she believed there was not a time that Youth A and Youth B were
able to get out of immediate supervision of her or any other staff
during their time placed at the facility together because of the
intentional efforts by staff.
Youth A was interviewed over the phone on 02/28/2023. She
confirmed that she has since moved from Camp Oakland facility
and is now placed in a detention center. Youth A recalled her time
placed at the facility with Youth B. Youth A stated that she noticed
that more cameras within the unit were put up the day that she
moved in, in November. Youth A stated that she recalled Youth B
attempting to form a relationship with her immediately after Youth
B moved in because they knew each other from a previous
placement. These attempts included attempting to pull Youth A
into rooms with her as well as sneaking into the back hallway
beyond camera supervision. Youth A stated that none of these
attempts ever actually advanced any further, and that there were
several occasions when staff noticed the two interacting. Youth A
4

stated that she had received instructions shortly after Youth B
move moved in that the two youth had to be at least six feet apart
at all times and we’re not allowed to sit near each other while
eating or during any group activities. Youth A confirmed the similar
conversations that Supervisor 1 had described in regard to safe
behaviors. Youth A reiterated that she had never had any sexual
interaction with Youth B, nor had any behaviors past verbal
communication that were inappropriate during their time placed
together.
Youth B was interviewed over the phone on 02/28/2023. She
confirmed that she had been previously placed at the facility with
Youth A and that she also knew Youth A from a prior placement in
2022. Youth B denied ever having any sort of physical or sexual
contact with Youth A. She also described her experiences with
staff supervision while placed at the facility. She stated that staff
were always on their feet and standing in the hallway or in the
common areas in order to supervise youth. Youth B did recall that
there were a couple of blind spots on the cameras in the units, but
that staff were very aware and worked to disallow youth from
going to those areas. Youth B stated that, while she disagreed
with the reasoning, she remembered having her room moved
down the hallway away from Youth A. Youth B believed that the
rules were getting more strict on interactions between youth as
she was placed because she heard other youth state as such.
Youth B stated that she also did not agree with the reasoning
behind the enhanced supervision and requirements on her safety
plan that was started while placed at the facility, but she also
agreed to the terms of it, and did not have any trouble following it.
Staff 2 and Staff 3 were interviewed over the phone separately on
02/28/2023. Both staff stated that they had concerns between
Youth A and Youth B while placed at the facility, but they believed
that their supervision was sufficient and prevented the two youths
from ever doing anything inappropriate between each other during
their time placed there. Both staff denied ever witnessing Youth A
and Youth B being physical with each other or being able to sneak
away from staff supervision.
Staff 4 was interviewed over the phone on 03/01/2023. She stated
that she had previously worked at the facility during the time of
Youth A and Youth B’s placement. She denied ever witnessing
these two youths doing anything inappropriate with each other and
stated that she was well aware of the concerns that others had
and the enhanced measures that were taken to ensure safety
5

between the two youths. She believed that those measures were
successful.
Documents reviewed:
• PREA Screening Tool dated 11/30/2022 for Youth A
outlining expectations for behavior management and
standards of conduct for youth.
• PREA Screening Tool dated 12/22/2022 for Youth B
outlining expectations for behavior management and
standards of conduct for youth.
• Treatment Team Meeting Agenda dated 12/28/2022 that
covered concerns between various youth and physical
distancing and staff supervising and correcting any
inappropriate language between youth. Supervisor 1 noted
that this conversation was in part caused by interactions
witnessed between Youth A and Youth B upon Youth B’s
placement.
• Treatment Team Meeting Agenda dated 01/04/2023 that
covers Youth B having her bedroom moved away from
Youth A because of PREA concerns.
• Safety Plan for Youth B dated 01/11/2023, signed by Youth
B. The cause is stated that she was displaying
inappropriate behavior and boundaries towards peers
causing PREA concerns. The proactive interventions listed
consisted of minimum spacing between the youth and other
youth as well as requirements to log inappropriate
behaviors.
• Facility Line of Sight policy last revised January 2018. It
requires youth to be under direct supervision of staff while
in the units with direct supervision defined as being in the
best reasonable physical position to ensure visual contact
with the youth.
• Internal PREA investigation authored by Supervisor 1 dated
01/26/2023. This report contained similar allegations to
what was received by DCWL to begin this investigation.
Youth A was interviewed by Supervisor 1 on 01/21/2023.
Youth A alleged that Youth B had propositioned Youth A to
perform sexual acts and has attempted to kiss her during
late December, but that Youth A did not want to participate
in those acts. Youth A stated that Youth B had still asked
about doing sexual things in the month of January but that
staff supervision did not allow these behaviors to occur.
Analysis Through face-to-face and phone interviews of youth and staff and
documentation reviewed there was not evidence found of any lack
of supervision of youth at the facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
